transcripts.text: Hello, I'm Guinus the Mirror.

We haven't done this, so we've been here since we lived here.  We haven't been for... Yeah, I don't know when we were on holiday, but not since we've lived here.  We haven't been to a family's house for a traditional meal.
How's the experience been so far?  Excellent.  Excellent.  Loving it, loving it, loving it.
Okay, so I'm Juliet from my husband Adrian.
Yes, I'm Adrian from Blacksit.

Yeah, we're all from Blacksit.  Yeah, we're all about the repatriation back home to the motherland.  We're living in Gambia.  This is Amma.  She's just Blacksit as well.  So she's come here to live.  We've come here to live permanently.  Enjoying life here, actually.  These are our children.  Hello, children.  That's Jeffrey and Tamara.  Say hi.  Look at the camera.  So yeah, we're big fans of yours.  Thank you, thank you.  We've been following you for years and in fact you inspired us.
And hang on, turn around.
Hey, McKennan, turn around.  Say hi.
Say hello to everybody.
Say hello.  Yeah, so McKennan's also a fan.  and uh he's the cameraman and the video editor.
okay he's the cameraman too.
okay man of many hats yeah that's our shop there.
oh that's your shop.  oh okay we got.  um when we come back oh you got ice cream too.  yeah okay yeah when we come back.
yeah yeah we make home i make homemade ice cream.  my brother and i oh man i gotta I gotta have a homemade ice cream.  I gotta have a homemade ice cream.  You definitely will.
Oh my goodness.

So yeah.  So we basically got fed up.  of living in England.  Our children suffer terribly from racism.  We suffer terribly from racism.  It became a really high profile story in the media.  And as a such, we became targeted.  So we realized that life just wasn't good for us there.  As black people, life was getting worse.  And with the Brexit, we realized it was time to black sit.  So yeah, the Black Sea was our re-entry back home to Africa.  And to be honest with you, it's the best decision I've ever made in my life.  The best decision I've ever made in my life.
I'm more happy.

Well, I'm not even more happy.  I am ecstatically happy.  Being around your own people, smell that food, smell that.  Oh yeah, smell it.  Being around your own people and living a genuine life.  Because it's genuine.  You're not living like... I think Joe said it's a double consciousness.
Right.
Yeah, we're not living a double consciousness anymore.  We're living a single consciousness.
I know exactly another feeling.
Another feeling.  Like for me, when I was in corporate America, a realization that, I know what you're talking about, like you're black, but you're like in white corporate America.
Yes.
I know exactly what you're talking about.
Yeah.  You're trying to get this black African identity, but you're in white corporate America.

Exactly.  You know, you have one face in corporate America, then you have the other one.  Another face when you go home.  You know, and then you go home, it's like, damn, I'm faking it in corporate America.
Why can't I just be myself?
Yeah, you know what it's like.
I know exactly what you're talking about.

Yeah, even Wodermeyer, because I was talking to Wodermeyer about you.  And we were talking, he's also a big fan of yours as well.  I think we all are.  But, you know, and you've inspired all of us, really, on our journeys, you know.  You showed us it's possible.  Right.  Possible to come, even.  You know what I mean?  To come, because remember, we have fears.  Right.  And these fears are instinctive and they're built over time.  When you live in the West, all they do is they show you... Can you turn the radio down a little bit for me, Lamin, please?  Lamin, can you turn the radio down for me, please?  What they do is they instinctively build up, if you like, layers and layers and layers of fears and a lot of insecurities.  And part of that insecurity is even to your own people.  Right.  So when you see the vision of Africans or Africa, you don't see yourself.  Right.  You don't see a reflection of yourself.  You see other than self.  That's me.  And so that's what happened to us.
Don't take all the money out the bank.  Don't take all the money out the bank.  I said don't take all the money.

Oh, okay.  Save some money for us.  Save some money for us.  They have no value, but they value money.  It's the only thing that they value.  And so the only power that we have is to take the money out.
Okay.

Yeah?  That's what we have to do.  Because if you're going to try to get reparations politically, it's not going to happen.  Because they don't respect you.  They never have.  Like Amma said, it's the illusion of inclusion.  We have to stop being under this illusion of inclusion and realise where home is.  Home is not where we were born, essentially, in the West.  Home is where our ancestors came from.  The problem that we have is that that information has been robbed from us, taken from us, stolen from us, you know, whipped from us, tortured from us, killed from us, raped from us.  And the worst part about it is the whole painful journey has not been talked about them doing anything about it.  They don't care.  They do not care.  The only way to, like I said, to get out of the situation is to leave it behind.
Leave it behind.  Pull your money out.
Pull your money.  That's the first thing you do.  You take out.  I met a lady from Kansas near and she told me that she got reparations.
How?  Break it down.  I'll package it.

I'll package it.  Okay.  So, and I told this story to the African Union, actually.  Well, she was from Kansas.  I'm not going to say her name, but, you know, for what she did.  But she told me, so I said to her, what did you do?  She goes, well, I cleared my credit.  And she's playing a really deep American accent.  I'm trying to imitate her.  She goes, I cleared my credit.  You got rid of your debt.  so i said what do you mean?  you cleared your line of credit.  she goes well you know i had a couple things on there.  yeah so i cleared it.  credit card.  yeah.  so she goes.

i said okay what else did you do?  she goes well i planned it i realized i wanted to come home to africa and i realized i didn't have the money.  hey uh your country accent is actually pretty good.  your kansas accent is not that bad?  yeah yeah it's actually pretty good.  yeah you sound like somebody from cancer.  sorry this is how she sounded.  i loved it.

yeah yeah yeah and you know.  so she said um you know and i i realized so she i planned it.  she said she planned to get 10 credit cards.  she got 10 credit cards and she got some loans.  she noticed she counted that she needed ninety thousand dollars so she got all her loans.  She got all her loans and her credit cards almost simultaneously.
Right.  And then simultaneously.
And then what she did was she ordered her containers, she booked her flight using her credit cards, she used the loans, made minimum payments across all the loans so she would not go to deficit.
She transferred the money out of America to her African bank account.  Right.
And then she kept making the minimum payments until she left.  And then she said she's in a new jurisdiction now.
She doesn't have to pay it back.
She said she got the $90,000, which was her reparation.  And she said, thank you.  God bless America.
It's funny you said that because we were having a discussion the other day on how you should clear all your debts before you come to Africa.
Some people are saying you need to be credit, you know, you need to be debt-free before you leave the continent, before you leave Africa for...
before you leave America for Africa.  But you're saying she did it, she kind of did it the other way around.  Yeah, what she did, she was really clever.
I think she's incredibly clever.  So she knew what she was going to do.  So she took as many loans as she could, secured against everything that she could, because she knew she was leaving.
Right.

So because she knew she was leaving, she was able to then use the credit card to fill containers to send it.  Right.  So she used the credit card and went on a spending match, so she got the highest amount that she could get on her credit card and filled the containers, you know.  She said she flew her, I think, business class or something that she paid for on the credit card.  Mm-hmm.  So she said, no, these banks were part of slavery.  These banks earned from slavery and everything they got was as a result of slavery.  So therefore, she's taking her money back.  And that's what she did.  So, no, don't clear anything.  You're in a new jurisdiction.  What are they going to do?  New laws, new country, new life.  They can't do nothing.  Take everything you can get from every single bank you can get, every single institution you can get and come home.  Why not?  They stole from you in the first place.  And what she said to me, what she said to me, which I found really, really interesting, she said to me that all of these banks have indemnity policies.
Seven years.  Seven years.  Yeah.  Seven years.

So these indemnity policies pay back the debt.  So they're not actually out of debt anyway.  Not that you should care.  The debt that you've taken is going to be paid back.  They're not actually losing anything anyway.

I think how it is with your credit, it'll be removed from your credit.  I don't know if it's the same in the UK, but in America, it'll be removed from your credit after seven years.  Yeah, so you have seven good years.  Enjoy yourself with your money.  But I think they can still sue you.

They can sue you, but what are they going to sue you here?  They don't even know where you live.  What's your address?  You have a street name in Gambia?  Yeah.  You don't.  You have to turn right by the bakery, left by the shop.  Where are they going to find it?  If you have no money, what are they going to do?

Another, I guess, argument against not leaving the West.  People say, well, the infrastructure is terrible in Africa.  It's terrible.  The infrastructure is bad.  So people who say that the infrastructure is bad here in Africa as an excuse not to leave America are brave.

Come and make it better.  I say the same thing.  If you think it's bad, come and make it better.  But the fact of the matter is not everywhere in England is good.  Not everywhere in America is good.  I've seen Skid Row.  You're telling me that Skid Row is good?  What about you?  build up Skid Row first then?  You understand?  That's my argument.  My argument is no way in the world is perfect.  And no infrastructure is perfect.  If there was infrastructure was perfect, you wouldn't have poverty.  In England, you wouldn't have food banks.  You wouldn't have homelessness.  In America, you wouldn't have homelessness.
You wouldn't have food banks.

This is the situation.  You wouldn't have poverty anywhere in the world.  You wouldn't even need a benefit system or Medicare.  The fact is that you do because your infrastructure doesn't support everybody.  In the same way that Africa, the infrastructure doesn't support everybody.
But I'll be damned to say that any lack of infrastructure stopped me from living my best life.
I'm living my best life in this infrastructure, so it can't be that bad.
In fact, I think it's pretty good.

I think they've exaggerated the issues around infrastructure.  They've exaggerated it in order, you know, to stop you from coming.  Don't let them do that.  Don't let them do that.  Right now we're visiting a Gambian family.
Okay, let me turn the camera off.
You ready, McKenna?  You turn your camera on.
